summary: Self-motivated, proactive lecturer with 8+ years of experience teaching courses at undergraduate and postgraduate levels. I did my M.Phil. in Physics with a Specialization in "Fiber optics and photonics". Possesses extensive scientific knowledge ( Physics, Engineering, and technology ) and its application to the laboratory. I specialize in the fields of condensed matter physics, electronics, and communication devices, applied optics. My carrier objective is to share knowledge by serving as faculty and to contribute to my field of interest by doing active research.

profile_positions.description:
•	Established nanomaterials processing lab in the Department of physics. carried and extensive literature review on shape and size control of nanoparticles prepared using chemical route.
•	I developed a micellar chemical reduction method of synthesize a range of metallic and semiconducting nanomaterials of various shapes and size by forming nano - reactors of surfactant - water- oil mixture. Moreover, I fabricated nano island and sub-micrometer ﬁlm by selective deposition of nanoparticles using an electrophoretic technique. Investing structural, morphological, and electrical characteristics of these nanostructures by XRD, SEM, and I/V techniques.
•	Trained and supervised bachelor's and master's degree students on nanomaterials synthesis in the lab.
•	As a lecturer, I prepared lectures and taught solid-state physics, Quantum mechanics, and electronics to bachelor's degree students. Developed physics demonstration, and experimental learning opportunities to clarify diﬃcult concepts and make topics relevant to students. Motivated students to explore, research, and apply physics concepts in and outside of class.

profile_positions.description: • In this project I have calculated the band gap energies of InAs, PbS, and PbSe narrow band gap quantum dots. The potential well energies, that conﬁnes electrons in three dimensions, and the Coulomb energy (the average value of Coulomb repulsion existing between an electron and a hole) were considered in the lowest states of the potential well. I observed that the smaller the diameter of the quantum dot, the more conﬁned the movements of the electrons and holes and this raises the energy necessary to excite the electron into the conduction band. Due to this, the band gap energies decreased with the increasing diameter of the quantum dots. The calculated band gap energies were compared with reported values (experimentally observed as well as theoretically calculated) in these quantum dots and found that my results agree with experimentally observed values only at lower radii.
